fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An (elementary) topos is a finitely complete and cartesian closed category equipped with a subobject classifier.

Let \mathcal {C} be a category with pullbacks. The subobject classifier of \mathcal {C} is the terminal object (if it exists) of the category \mathcal {S}_{\mathcal {C}} defined by the following data:

html:tr.html:td: An object of \mathcal {S}_{\mathcal {C}} is a pair (A, m), where A is an object in \mathcal {C} and m\colon A' \rightarrowtail A is a subobject.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Identities and compositions of \mathcal {S}_{\mathcal {C}} are inherited from \mathcal {C}.
An (elementary) topos is a finitely complete and cartesian closed category equipped with a subobject classifier.
Let A be any object in a topos and let \{\}\colon A \to \Omega ^{A} be the name of the diagonal relation \Delta \colon A \rightarrowtail A \times A. \{\} is a monomorphism.

Let m\colon R\rightarrowtail A \times B be a relation in a topos. The name of m is the exponential transpose \nu _{m}\colon B \to \Omega ^{A} of the classifier \chi _{m}\colon A \times B \to \Omega of m.
Every topos is balanced.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: By , every monomorphism is regular. Thus, any epic monomorphism is automatically an isomorphism.

fr:title.text: Separated objects correspond to closed diagonal relations

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Separated objects correspond to closed diagonal relations

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An object A of a topos \mathcal {E} is separated iff the diagonal subobject \Delta \colon A \rightarrowtail A \times A is closed.
A (Lawvere-Tierney) topology on a topos \mathcal {E} is a morphism j\colon \Omega \to \Omega satisfying the following equations.
Let j be a topology on a topos. A subobject m\colon A \rightarrowtail B is said to be j-closed if its closure is isomorphic to itself.
Let j be a topology on a topos. Let m\colon A \rightarrowtail B be a subobject. The j-closure of m is the subobject classified by j\chi _{m}\colon B \to \Omega .
Let j be a topology on a topos. A subobject m\colon A \rightarrowtail B is said to be j-dense if its closure is an isomorphism.

Let j be a topology on a topos \mathcal {E}. An object S \in \mathcal {E} is said to be j-separated if for any dense subobject m\colon A \rightarrowtail B and any morphism f\colon A \to S, there is at most one morphism g\colon B \to S such that f = gm.

Let j be a topology on a topos \mathcal {E}. An object S \in \mathcal {E} is said to be a j-sheaf if for any dense subobject m\colon A \rightarrowtail B and any morphism f\colon A \to S, there is exactly one morphism g\colon B \to S such that f = gm.

fr:title.text: Subobjects of separated objects are separated

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subobjects of separated objects are separated

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A be a separated object in a topos \mathcal {E}. Any subobject m\colon A' \rightarrowtail A is separated.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Let m'\colon B' \rightarrowtail B be a dense subobject and f\colon B' \to A' be any morphism. If f = gm' = hm' then mf = mgm' = mhm'. First, mg = mh because A is separated. Then it follows that g = h because m is a monomorphism.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {E} and \mathcal {F} be topoi. A geometric morphism f\colon \mathcal {E}\to \mathcal {F} is an adjoint pair of functors
such that f^{*} is left exact. The functors f_{*} and f^{*} are called the direct image and the inverse image respectively.
Let \mathcal {E} and \mathcal {F} be topoi. A logical functor F\colon \mathcal {E}\to \mathcal {F} is a functor preserving finite limits, exponentials, and the subobject classifier.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In a topos, every monomorphism is an equalizer.
